Coordination synergy between metal nanoclusters and ruthenium photosensitizers for photocatalytic cycloaddition of CO2 under mild conditions Yongwang Wei Writing – original draft Software Methodology Data curation Longchao Du Supervision Project administration Investigation Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Haiyun Gao Validation Software Methodology Data curation School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering & the Key Laboratory of Environment-Friendly Polymer Materials of Anhui Province, Key Laboratory of Structure and Functional Regulation of Hybrid Materials (Anhui University), Ministry of Education, Anhui University, Hefei 230601, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering & the Key Laboratory of Environment-Friendly Polymer Materials of Anhui Province Key Laboratory of Structure and Functional Regulation of Hybrid Materials (Anhui University) Ministry of Education Anhui University Hefei 230601 PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering & the Key Laboratory of Environment-Friendly Polymer Materials of Anhui Province, Key Laboratory of Structure and Functional Regulation of Hybrid Materials (Anhui University), Ministry of Education, Anhui University, Hefei 230601, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Highly active catalysts can directly utilize renewable energy sources, and are ideal for CO2 appreciation processes. In order to improve the efficiency of light-driven CO2 cycloaddition reaction, photosensitizer and metal nanocluster catalyst were synthesized, and the photocatalyst with high photosensitive activity was obtained by coordination bond. This has been confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, ultraviolet spectroscopy and density functional theory. With the help of coordination bonds, the light absorption and light response of metal nanocluster catalysts are significantly enhanced, which has been demonstrated by transient photocurrent, electrochemical impedance and electron paramagnetic tests. The results of CO2 cycloaddition showed that the photocatalytic system with coordination synergism (RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4) showed high catalytic activity (TON=1723), and the conversion rate of CO2 cycloaddition reached 98.7 % under mild conditions. Moreover, the cyclic test results indicate that the catalytic activity of the photocatalytic system hardly deteriorates after more than five uses. This study provides a new possibility for photocatalytic cycloaddition of CO2 under mild conditions. Graphical abstract Synopsis: The synthesized photosensitizer (RuPyL2) was mixed with metal nanoclusters (Mn2Ni4) in equimolar ratios to obtain a photocatalytic system with coordination synergy (RuPyL2/ Mn2Ni4). The photoelectric measurement results indicate that with the help of coordination bonds, the electron transfer efficiency of the photocatalyst is greatly improved. Applied to the CO2 cycloaddition reaction, it exhibited excellent catalytic performance, with a maximum cycloaddition conversion rate of 98.7 % and a TON value of 1723 at room temperature and normal pressure. This is of great significance for the study of novel photocatalytic carbon dioxide cycloaddition reactions. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Photocatalysis Metal nanoclusters Coordination synergy CO2 utilization Cyclic carbonate Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the intensification of the industrialization process, the use of fossil fuels has been increasing in recent decades, and the growth of CO2 in the atmosphere has been very rapid, posing a huge threat to the sustainable development of human society and the ecological environment [1–3]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to capture and convert CO2. However, CO2 is also a non-toxic, abundant and renewable C1 resource [4–9], which can be fixed into a variety of high value-added chemical products, such as methanol, amide, cyclic carbonates [10–13]. One of the most effective ways is to fix CO2 into epoxides to form ring carbonates. Cyclic carbonates are widely used, such as in the synthesis of polyurethane [14,15], aprotic polar solvents [16], and electrolyte batteries [17]. At present, catalysts such as ionic liquids [18,19], Schiff bases [20,21], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [22] and covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [23] have been developed for CO2 cycloaddition reactions. However, most of these catalysts require relatively harsh conditions such as high temperature and high pressure. Therefore, achieving this reaction under mild conditions is a challenge [24]. In this context, using sunlight/visible light as a driving force to promote carbon dioxide cycloaddition reactions is a very promising way to achieve this challenge. In order to make better use of sunlight/visible light [25–30], a series of photocatalysts such as ACN-Ag [31], Al−N4/porous carbon [32] and Bi-PCN-224 [33] have been synthesized in recent years. It has been observed that both photosensitive activity and Lewis acid effect are important in the cycloaddition reaction of CO2. In this work, photosensitizer (PS) is combined with nanoclusters (NCs) catalyst to design a catalytic system with Lewis acid [34] effect and high photocatalytic activity. On the one hand, reducing the catalyst size to the nanometer scale can maximize the exposure of the active site, thereby improving catalytic activity [35–39]. In addition, transition metals have a strong Lewis acid effect, and the introduction of transition metals in NCs can further improve its catalytic activity [40]. On the other hand, terpyridine ligands, as one of the most efficient PS ligands, have a high potential for photocatalytic applications, showing excellent stability and photochemical ability in pairing with low valence metals [41]. Ruthenium (Ru) is an excellent element for classical photosensitizer with excellent visible light capturing ability and high electron transfer efficiency [42–46]. By combining metal NCs catalyst with PS, a catalytic system with both photosensitive activity and Lewis acid effect can be obtained. The catalytic performance of the photocatalytic system is greatly affected by the electron transfer rate between the catalyst and PS [47]. Only recently have photocatalytic systems been developed that use covalent bonds to connect PS to catalysts, the covalent attachment between the Os(II)-Re(I)-Ru(II) catalyst and the PS groups, studied by Ishitani et al. [48]. This connection method exhibits rapid intramolecular charge transfer. But this connection is very fragile and has a fatal weakness - reverse electron transfer through covalent bonds leads to irreversible loss of stability and activity [49,50]. Coordination bond is a kind of special covalent bond with dynamic interaction. Its reversible nature makes the coordination bond self-correcting, which is an ideal way for PS to connect with the catalyst. At present, this synergistic effect has been used for hydrogen evolution of molecular systems [51–53] or immobilization of molecular catalysts on heterogeneous materials [54,55]. However, photocatalyzed cycloaddition reactions of CO2 rarely utilize the coordination synergies between PS and the catalyst. In this work, we have designed a binuclear Ru(II) PS with pyridine end groups, RuPyL2, and one metal NCs catalysts, Mn2Ni4. The RuPyL2 pyridine terminal group can be used as the binding site to form the photocatalytic system RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 by coordination with Ni. In addition, three binuclear Ru(II) PS without coordination capability were synthesized for comparison, RuBrL2, RuCH3L2 and RuPhL2. The catalytic properties of these catalysts involved in the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 at specific wavelengths of visible light were investigated. The catalytic mechanism was analyzed. As expected, the RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 photocatalytic system with coordination synergism showed extremely high catalytic performance at ambient temperature and normal pressure (TON=1723). Compared with a single Mn2Ni4 catalyst (TON=656), the catalytic performance was increased by 2.6 times. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of the photocatalyst Terpyridine ligands were synthesized according to literature reports (Scheme 1 a) [56–59]. L2 reacts with RuCl3·3H2O in a molar ratio of 1:2 to form an intermediate (RuL2Cl6). Ru(II) PS (RuBrL2, RuCH3L2, RuPhL2, RuPyL2) is prepared by the reaction of the intermediate with the terpyridine ligand under the condition of triethylamine as reducing agent and the molar ratio of 1:2. The structure and composition of Ru(II) PS were confirmed by 1H NMR and mass spectrometry (Figs. S1–S8). The UV–visible absorption (UV) of Ru(II) PS in acetonitrile was studied, and relevant data were shown in Fig. S9. Metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) leaps (Ru(II) to terpyridine ligand) of RuBrL2, RuCH3L2, RuPhL2, RuPyL2 form relatively strong bands at 498, 500, 504, and 500 nm, respectively. The transition of MLCT at around 500 nm is comparable to that of other reported Ru(II) PS complexes [60]. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was used to test the thermal stability of RuPyL2. See Fig. S10a for relevant data. The decomposition temperature of RuPyL2 is 400 °C (7.7 % weight loss), which confirms that the photosensitizer has good thermal stability. The synthesis pathway of metal NCs is as follows (Scheme 1b). The valeric acid was dissolved in acetonitrile and heated to boiling, then Bun 4NMnO4 [61] (Bun, n‑butyl), Mn(CH3CO2)2·4H2O, Ni(CH3CO2)2·2H2O were added, then heated and stirred to obtain the precursor. Under the condition of 2 % pyridine, the precursor was recrystallized in ethyl acetate to obtain Mn2Ni4 NCs [62], the molecular formula is [Mn2Ni4O2(ButCO2)10(py)4] (But, tert‑butyl; py, pyridine), whose detailed crystal data are shown in Fig. 1 and Table S1. The structure and composition of Mn2Ni4 NCs were systematically analyzed by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), TG, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). After the SCXRD test results were analyzed by Olex2 software, as shown in Fig. 1, the core of metal NCs consists of 6 O and 6 metals. The outer layer is wrapped in pyridine and But to maintain stability. The thermal stability of Mn2Ni4 NCs was studied by TG (After the SCXRD test results were analyzed by Olex2 software, as shown in Fig. S10b. The decomposition temperature was 189 °C (weight loss was 6.5 %), which confirmed that Mn2Ni4 NCs had good thermal stability. The TEM (Fig. 1d) showed that Mn2Ni4 NCs were homogeneous ellipsoidal particles. This shape can provide a larger active surface area and more active sites for catalytic reactions, which is more conducive to the adhesion of CO2 and epoxides, thereby improving the efficiency of the cycloaddition reaction. Mixing the synthesized Ru(II) PS with metal NCs in equimolar ratios to obtain photocatalytic systems: RuBrL2/Mn2Ni4, RuCH3L2/Mn2Ni4, RuPhL2/Mn2Ni4 and RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4. TG was used to test the thermal stability of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4. See Fig. S10c for relevant data. The decomposition temperature of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 is 165 °C (4.3 % weight loss), which confirms that the RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 photocatalytic system has good thermal stability. 2.2 Coordination synergies between photosensitizers and metal NCs catalysts The coordination environment of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 was determined by XPS, UV and density functional theory (DFT). The N1s spectrum (Fig. 2 a) shows that RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 has a clear new peak at 402.4 eV, which is not present in the N1s spectrum of Mn2Ni4 NCs or RuPyL2. This finding indicates that the terminal pyridine group of RuPyL2 is successfully coordinated with the metal atom in Mn2Ni4 NCs [63]. In addition, after mixing Mn2Ni4 NCs with RuPyL2, the binding energies of Mn2p (Fig. 2b), Ru3p (Fig. 2c) and Ni2p (Fig. 2d) changed significantly compared with before mixing. The most significant change is in Ni2p. Specifically, the Mn2p peak moves −0.4 eV, the Ni2p peak moves −0.6 eV, and the Ru3p peak moves −0.3 eV. This result indicates that introducing the photosensitizer RuPyL2 into Mn2Ni4 NCs increases the electron cloud density of Mn2Ni4 NCs, so the peaks move to the direction of lower energy. This in turn reflects the one-to-one coordination of the nitrogen atom at the end of RuPyL2 with the Ni atom in Mn2Ni4 NCs [64]. In addition, the C1 s spectrum (Fig. S11) shows that after the addition of RuPyL2, Mn2Ni4 NCs did not form new carbon bonds, ruling out the possibility of metalization at other sites. The UV spectra of RuPyL2, Mn2Ni4 NCs, and RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 were tested under the same conditions. The experimental results show (Fig. 2e) that the absorption peak position of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 is redshifted by 6 nm compared with a single RuPyL2. This phenomenon indicates the existence of coordination bonds between RuPyL2 and Mn2Ni4 NCs, which can induce electron transfer and lead to electron level rearrangement. This energy level reconstruction affects the absorption peak wavelength of RuPyL2 and the energy difference of electronic transitions [65]. To eliminate the possibility of interference from other coordination moieties on the peak shift of RuPyL2 absorption, RuPhL2 was used instead of RuPyL2 and mixed with Mn2Ni4 NCs for UV test (Fig. 2f). RuPhL2 is a PS without pyridine groups on both sides. As shown in Fig. 2f, the absorption peak of RuPhL2/Mn2Ni4 shifts from 504 nm to 505 nm, with a redshift of only 1 nm. This indicates that mixing RuPhL2 with Mn2Ni4 NCs has almost no effect on the absorption peak of Mn2Ni4 NCs. The comparative experiment excluded the influence of other coordination. The experiment results are consistent with those of the above XPS experiment. The synergistic effect between RuPyL2 and Mn2Ni4 NCs has been further demonstrated. 2.3 Coordination synergies between photosensitizers and metal NCs catalysts In order to further verify the coordination between the terminal pyridine group of RuPyL2 and Ni, DFT optimized the structures of RuPyL2, Mn2Ni4, and RuPyL2-Ni(Mn2Ni4) using B3LYP/6-31G(d) method on Gaussian 09 program. For the convenience of calculation, the external ligands of Mn2Ni4 were omitted, and the core was retained. The energies of RuPyL2, Mn2Ni4, and RuPyL2-Ni(Mn2Ni4) are −4344.42 a.u., −1330.59 a.u., and −5680.91 a.u., respectively. Compared to the sum of the energies of RuPyL2 and Mn2Ni4. The energy of RuPyL2-Ni(Mn2Ni4) decreased by 5.90 a.u. This indicates that the terminal pyridine group of RuPyL2 has successfully coordinated with Ni in Mn2Ni4, which corresponds to the analysis results of XPS and UV. It is very feasible to use coordination bonds to connect PS with metal NCs. On the other hand, before connecting RuPyL2 with Mn2Ni4, the HOMO and LUMO orbitals on RuPyL2 are uniformly distributed (Fig. 3 ). After connecting RuPyL2 with Mn2Ni4, the HOMO orbitals mainly exist on RuPyL2, while the LUMO orbitals are mainly located on Mn2Ni4. This indicates that when RuPyL2 absorbs sunlight and generates electrons, they will be transferred to Mn2Ni4 through coordination bonds, which is consistent with the concept of this study. In order to further investigate the coordination of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4, we analyzed the results of RuPyL2, Mn2Ni4, and RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 using X-ray diffraction (XRD) testing. As shown in Fig. S12, RuPyL2 exhibits a broad reflection at approximately 22.7° of 2θ, indicating that it is an amorphous substance. On the contrary, the XRD pattern of Mn2Ni4 has high and sharp peaks, especially at 12.45° and 19.45°. This indicates that Mn2Ni4 has good crystallinity [28,66]. The XRD pattern of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 mainly shows a wide reflection of RuPyL2 at 22.7°. The peak intensity of Mn2Ni4 decreased at 12.45° and 19.45°. This may be because RuPyL2 is connected to Mn2Ni4 through coordination bonds, and Mn2Ni4 is encapsulated by RuPyL2, resulting in a decrease in the peak intensity of Mn2Ni4 in XRD spectra. The partial results of CO2 cycloaddition reaction are shown in Table 1 . The results show, the catalytic performance of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 photocatalytic systems with coordination synergies is significantly higher than other photocatalytic systems (6–9 and 24–26 of Table 1). Specifically, the TON value of the RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 photocatalytic system is 2.14 times that of a single Mn2Ni4 NCs catalyst (5 and 9 in Table 1) under photocatalytic conditions, and 1.4 times that of a single Mn2Ni4 NCs catalyst (23 and 27 in Table 1) under dark conditions. Fig. S14 shows that this enhancement is more pronounced in the early stages of the reaction, increasing by nearly 2.5 times. This indicates that the introduction of RuPyL2 significantly enhances the catalytic activity of Mn2Ni4 NCs. The entries 17 and 18 of Table 1 show that regardless of the introduction of RuCl3·3H2O or RuCl3·3H2O/Pytpy/L2 (2:2:1), there is no significant improvement in the catalytic performance of Mn2Ni4 NCs catalyst, further proving this point. Items 12–16 of Table 1 show that the catalytic properties of Mn(Ac)2, Ni(Ac)2, valeric acid, pyridine and physical mixtures of the four catalysts (molar ratio Mn(Ac)2:Ni(Ac)2:valeric acid:pyridine = 1:1:40:0.02) are all very low. However, after preparing these four catalysts into Mn2Ni4 NCs (5 of Table 1), the active sites can be maximally exposed, effectively increasing the specific surface area and improving the catalytic activity. Under photocatalytic conditions, the catalytic performance of Mn2Ni4 NCs is 3.51 times that of the physical mixture of these four catalysts. In addition, it can be seen from items 6 to 8 of Table 1 that RuCH3L2/Mn2Ni4, RuBrL2/Mn2Ni4, and RuPhL2/Mn2Ni4 catalysts without coordination synergy have limited improvement in catalytic performance compared to single Mn2Ni4 NCs catalysts. The catalytic properties of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 (9 of Table 1) systems having coordination synergies are 1.38, 1.33 and 1.27 times compared the three photocatalytic systems above, respectively. This proves that coordination synergies play an important role in improving photocatalytic efficiency. Comparative experiments showed that the yield of CO2 cycloaddition decreased significantly under dark conditions (27 of Table 1) or when the RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 photocatalytic system was removed (11 of Table 1), indicating that the introduction of light and efficient catalyst is a crucial step during CO2 cycloaddition under mild conditions. In addition, when removing the co catalyst TBAB, the yield of CO2 cycloaddition also significantly decreased (10 of Table 1), which is consistent with previous research results that TBAB is necessary for promoting epoxide ring opening [67]. In summary, the combination of light and TBAB, the RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 composite photocatalyst has achieved efficient photocatalytic CO2 cycloaddition reaction under mild conditions. In order to further study the catalytic performance of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 photocatalytic system, a variety of epoxides with different functional groups were catalyzed under the same cycloaddition conditions. Their conversion rates were determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy (Figs. S16–S20). As shown in Table S1, low steric hindrance epoxides with side groups -CH3, -C2H5 and -Cl can be efficiently converted into target products and maintain a high conversion rate. The reaction rates of oxidized styrene and 2,3-epoxy-propoxy-benzene are relatively low because of their large substituents and high steric resistance [65]. However, regardless of the functional group, the RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 photocatalytic system has good catalytic performance. After the cycloaddition reaction was completed, the recovered catalyst catalyzed CO2 and propylene oxide under the same conditions, and five cycle tests were carried out. The RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 catalytic system still maintained excellent performance (Fig. 4 a). The catalyst after catalytic cycling was tested by FT-IR and XRD (Fig. 4b and c), and it was found that there was no significant difference in the test results after the reaction. Indicating that the RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 catalytic system has long-term stability. In addition, Table S3 shows that the catalytic performance of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 composite photocatalyst in the cycloaddition reaction is comparable to the latest catalysts such as (Hf)PCN-224(Co), ZIS/ZNC-0.03, Co2C, VIRP-2, and Bi-PCN-224. 2.4 Photocatalytic mechanism of the RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 Light absorption and light response are important factors when evaluating photocatalytic systems [38,39,68]. Therefore, UV diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) was used to test Mn2Ni4 and RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 (Fig. 5 a). The experimental results showed that compared with using Mn2Ni4 alone, the introduction of RuPyL2 broadened the light absorption range and slightly shifted the absorption edge towards red. This indicates that the introduction of RuPyL2 significantly enhances the light absorption ability of Mn2Ni4. The photocharge separation efficiencies of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 were investigated by using transient photocurrent response and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). Both analyses were performed using three-electrode devices and xenon lamps as irradiation sources. The electrolyte is 0.1 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution added with ethanol-water mixture (V:V = 1:10), the light source is 300 w xenon lamp, the working electrode is coated with RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 tin oxide fluoride (FTO) glass, the reference electrode is Ag/AgCl, the counter electrode is platinum wire. To produce a photocurrent at a biased voltage, the holes created after the light is captured by a hole scavenger (in this case ethanol) and electrons are injected into the FTO layer for output [69,70]. On the one hand, as shown in Fig. 5b, the photocurrent of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 is more than 1.4 times that of Mn2Ni4. This significant increase can be due to the fact that the visible light absorption rate of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 is higher than that of Mn2Ni4. It also means that RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 has a higher interfacial charge separation efficiency than Mn2Ni4, which is consistent with the previous results on the catalytic performance of CO2 cycloaddition. On the other hand, in the EIS diagram (Fig. 5c), RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 has a smaller arc radius than Mn2Ni4, which indicates that RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 has a lower charge transfer resistance, resulting in more efficient charge separation [71]. The coordination bond in RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 may be an important reason for improving the efficiency of charge separation. As shown in the cyclic voltammetry curves of Mn2Ni4 and RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 in Fig. S15, compared with a single Mn2Ni4, the addition of RuPyL2 enhances the current response capability of Mn2Ni4 and increases the symmetry of the redox potential. This indicates that the introduction of PS not only enhances the catalytic activity of Mn2Ni4, but also strengthens their reversibility. This may be due to the synergistic effect between RuPyL2 and Mn2Ni4. In order to understand the transfer of photogenerated electrons, the RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 photocatalytic system was analyzed by in situ electron para-magnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy. The 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine oxide (TEMPO), which does not react with reactive oxygen species and electrons, was introduced into the test system as an electron capture agent. The Lorentz spectral signal with a g value of 2.0032 can be attributed to the lone pair electrons on the carbon atom in RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4, as previously reported [72] (Fig. 5d–g). EPR spectral tests show that the intensity of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 decreases considerably after light irradiation regardless of the atmosphere (Fig. 5d and e). This may be that the photogenerated electrons produced by RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 under light conditions are captured by TEMPO, thus reducing the intensity of the EPR peak. Under illumination conditions, compared with N2 atmosphere (IL, nitrogen/ID, nitrogen = 0.848, Fig. 5d), the EPR peak intensity ratio under CO2 atmosphere (IL, carbon dioxide/ID, carbon dioxide = 0.856, Fig. 5e) did not change significantly, indicating that photo generated electrons cannot be transferred to CO2. Indicating that RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 cannot activate CO2 to convert it into CO2 •−. On the contrary, after PO is injected into RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 system, the EPR intensity under light irradiation (IL, nitrogen, PO/ID, nitrogen = 0.905, Fig. 5f) increases obviously compared with the initial nitrogen atmosphere (IL, nitrogen/ID, nitrogen = 0.848, Fig. 5d), indicating that photogenerated electrons can be transferred to PO. In addition, it can be seen from Fig. 5g that the peak EPR intensity of RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 is lower than that of a single Mn2Ni4 NCs. This indicates that the photogenerated electrons increase when light is irradiated on RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4. 2.5 Catalytic mechanism of CO2 cycloaddition catalyzed by RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 Based on the above results and previous reports [73], a reasonable mechanism with coordination synergy was proposed for CO2 cycloaddition reaction using the RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 (Scheme 2). Firstly, the electrons generated by light are absorbed and transferred to the epoxide by the RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 photocatalytic system, resulting in epoxide activation. Due to the presence of coordination bonds, it promotes the transfer of electrons. Then, the nucleophilic attack of the cocatalyst TBAB activates and opens the epoxy ring. Next, the carbon atom of CO2 is attacked by the oxygen anion of the ring opening intermediate, thereby inserting carbon dioxide into the intermediate to form a bromocarbonate complex. In situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy was used to analyze this step, in order to track the cycloaddition reaction process of CO2 and epoxide. As shown in the Fig. 5, the characteristic absorption peak (C=O stretching vibration) of cyclic carbonates gradually increases at 1806 cm-1 (Fig. 5h) [74], while the stretching vibration of C-O-C for epoxides decreases at 1265 cm-1 (Fig. 5i) [75]. The above results indicate that the cycloaddition reaction between epoxides and carbon dioxide is effective. Finally, the closure of the ring molecule leads to the formation of cyclic carbonates and the regeneration of the catalyst. Therefore, the synergistic activation of photo generated electrons, the promotion of electron transfer by coordination bonds, and the use of bromide ions as nucleophiles to facilitate epoxide ring opening all contribute to the smooth progress of cycloaddition reactions. 3 Conclusions In this work, a new photocatalytic system with coordination synergy, RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4, was successfully synthesized. And as a powerful photocatalytic material, it can utilize CO2 to form cyclic carbonates through the cycloaddition reaction with epoxides. The RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 exhibits strong photocatalytic absorption in the visible light region. Importantly, RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4 exhibits efficient photocatalytic activity under mild reaction conditions. In summary, this design provides a new possibility for the rational utilization of coordination bonds to promote electron transfer and for CO2 cycloaddition under mild conditions. coredata.dc:description: Highly active catalysts can directly utilize renewable energy sources, and are ideal for CO2 appreciation processes. In order to improve the efficiency of light-driven CO2 cycloaddition reaction, photosensitizer and metal nanocluster catalyst were synthesized, and the photocatalyst with high photosensitive activity was obtained by coordination bond. This has been confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, ultraviolet spectroscopy and density functional theory. With the help of coordination bonds, the light absorption and light response of metal nanocluster catalysts are significantly enhanced, which has been demonstrated by transient photocurrent, electrochemical impedance and electron paramagnetic tests. The results of CO2 cycloaddition showed that the photocatalytic system with coordination synergism (RuPyL2/Mn2Ni4) showed high catalytic activity (TON=1723), and the conversion rate of CO2 cycloaddition reached 98.7 % under mild conditions. Moreover, the cyclic test results indicate that the catalytic activity of the photocatalytic system hardly deteriorates after more than five uses. This study provides a new possibility for photocatalytic cycloaddition of CO2 under mild conditions.
